title: High-Quality Leads Await With Revenos: eXp Realty‚Äôs Secret Sauce!
excerpt: Key Points: Revenos Division: A specialized division within eXp Realty focused on providing high-quality real estate leads. Tailored Matching: Connects agents with buyers and sellers…
content:
Key Points:

  • Revenos Division: A specialized division within eXp Realty focused on providing high-quality real estate leads.
  • Tailored Matching: Connects agents with buyers and sellers by aligning specific client needs and agent characteristics.
  • Program Variety: Offers programs like ExpressOffers, eXp Affinity, and more, tailored to enhance sales and agent success.
  • Proven Success: Generated over $2 billion in closed sales for eXp agents in 2024, showcasing its effectiveness.
  • Agent Support: Provides comprehensive training and support to ensure agents maximize their lead conversion opportunities.

Let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîreal estate agent leads can be a nightmare. You‚Äôre either paying out the nose for cold, unmotivated contacts or chasing tire-kickers who ghost after one text. Sound familiar?

Now imagine a brokerage that doesn‚Äôt just toss you scraps, but works full-time to feed you high-quality leads. Welcome to eXp Realty. It‚Äôs the only brokerage in the U.S. with an entire division‚ÄîRevenos‚Äîbuilt specifically to generate and deliver serious real estate agent leads. We‚Äôre talking buyers and sellers who are ready to go, not just “thinking about it.”

And these aren‚Äôt some hand-me-down leads from random websites or ancient call lists. They‚Äôre matched, nurtured, and sent straight to you, with options for relocation, military, iBuyer sellers, corporate clients, and more.

It‚Äôs time to stop chasing and start closing. Here‚Äôs your handy-dandy index:

eXp Realty‚Äôs Quality Leads
Revenos Magic?
Revenos Benefits?
How to Get Revenos Leads?
¬†Revenos Programs Explained

ExpressOffers
eXp Affinity
eXp Relocation
eXp Honor Military Rewards
eXp REO (Real Estate Owned)
Institutional Investment Services
eXp Bundle Select Program
Making it Rain
¬†Realtor Leads Pay at Closing?
Real Estate Agent Leads That Actually Work‚ÄîOnly at eXp Realty
Frequently Asked Questions

How are eXp Realty leads different than other brokerages?
Why are eXp Realty‚Äôs Revenos real estate agent leads special?
How do eXp agents get eXp Realty real estate leads?

eXp Realty‚Äôs Quality Leads

Real estate agent leads at eXp are the best in the business. This isn‚Äôt just a claim; it‚Äôs a proven fact. These quality leads are super special! They go WAY beyond the typical low-quality ones that result from someone clicking on some ad or phoning into a brokerage office.

Of course, eXp Realty provides those too, but what sets them apart is their dedicated real estate agent leads division, Revenos. This full-time division, stocked with a skilled team, leverages eXp Realty‚Äôs extensive network to unearth quality leads for eXp Realty agents.

And it‚Äôs working! In 2024, Revenos provided thousands of top-quality real estate agent leads,¬†generating over $2 billion in closed sales¬†for eXp agents. The year 2025 promises even more success!

Revenos Magic

Revenos is lead magic for agents. Why?

  • Quality Lead Sources: Revenos does the heavy lifting to find and nurture top-tier lead sources.
  • High Conversions by Matching Leads with Agents: Revenos digs deep, identifying client characteristics that match them perfectly with an eXp agent. For instance, if a client loves hiking, Revenos will find an agent who shares that passion, creating a connection that boosts value and successful closings.
  • Agent Choices with Different Programs:¬†Revenos offers eight distinct programs under its umbrella. Each program provides a specific type of lead, allowing agents to choose what suits them best. These programs include ExpressOffers, eXp Affinity, eXp Relocation, eXp Honor Military Rewards, eXp REO (Real Estate Owned), Institutional Investment Services, Bundle Select, and Making It Rain.

Revenos Benefits

Revenos leads are, as CEO Leo Pareja states, ‚Äúan unparalleled offering in the real estate industry.‚Äù Here‚Äôs why:

Exclusive to eXp Agents: All leads are exclusively for eXp agents.

Continuous Growth: Revenos growth is exploding with its:

  • Strategic Network Expansion: Revenos is always looking for new opportunities.
  • Informative Training: Revenos offers actionable training to set agents up for success.
  • Proven Success: Revenos demonstrates a record of delivering quality leads and referrals.

How to Get Revenos Leads

  • Become an eXp Agent: Join the eXp Realty family and remember to pick a great eXp sponsor like Smart Agent Alliance.
  • Get Training: Enroll in the Revenos certification training program of your choice to gain the knowledge, confidence, and expertise needed to represent clients exceptionally.¬† Or, better yet, enroll in all the Revenos certification training programs so you‚Äôll be set to conquer any lead type.
  • Gain Qualifications: Gain the standards preferred by Revenos clients to increase your chances of being chosen for the real estate leads.
  • Note the Gray Area: Even if you don’t meet a client‚Äôs preferred qualifications, there are situations when you will still be the chosen agent.¬† So don‚Äôt delay in getting certified for maximum opportunity.

¬†Revenos Programs Explained

Let‚Äôs get into the various eXp referral programs and their agent qualifications. Remember, all programs are open to all eXp Agents, and all training is completely FREE. And, yes, this is on top of the arsenal of other eXp training.

ExpressOffers

ExpressOffers is a platform that aggregates multiple iBuyers (including Opendoor), ready to quickly make cash offers to sellers. eXp agents are assigned these quality leads and can earn commissions from both negotiating terms with the seller and listing the home if the iBuyer puts it back on the market.

  • Certification Format: On-Demand Course
  • Preferred Client Qualifications: ExpressOffers Certification only

eXp Affinity

eXp Affinity partners with large companies that provide various real estate-related services to their clients. Revenos forms relationships with these companies to be their source of supplying real estate agents. eXp Affinity currently includes five companies that provide these quality leads to eXp agents.

Certification Format: One Live Class offered once a month

Client Qualifications:¬† Agents should meet the specific qualifications of the providing company.¬† Currently, those preferred client qualifications start with full-time agents who have been licensed for 2 years and have done 12 transactions in the prior 12 months.

eXp Relocation

eXp Relocation works with corporations to provide services to their employees who need to transfer to a different location. eXp Relocations matches local eXp agents to these corporate transferee clients.

Certification Format: Live courses

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† Minimum of one year of experience

eXp Honor Military Rewards

eXp Honor Military Rewards assists active duty, veterans, and retired service members from our US armed forces with their real estate needs.

Certification Format: Get Relocations certified in live courses

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† Minimum of one year of experience

eXp REO (Real Estate Owned)

eXp agents manage and list REO properties, providing expertise in assisting financial institutions, investors, and government agencies. REO refers to any property that is taken back through either a legal foreclosure, Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure, or any other properties or notes purchased at a court foreclosure auction. REO properties may also be called Corporate Owned, Bank Owned, or Bank Repo properties.

Certification Format: Live Training

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† Minimum of two years of REO experience; licensed for at least three years; experience in repair management, renovations, or property management; possesses a network of local vendors.

Institutional Investment Services

Institutional Investment Services helps some of the world‚Äôs largest landlords invest in or sell single-family rental properties by connecting them with top-performing eXp agents for expert support.

Certification Format: live training

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† Experience working with investors

eXp Bundle Select Program

Bundle Select offers bundled real estate services to corporations and organizations, saving employees 20% or more on transaction fees and providing 24/7 concierge support.

Revenos provides eXp agents with customized websites and videos to educate corporations and organizations about Bundle Select‚Äôs immense value.

This is not a little deal! Currently,¬†over 6 million employees¬†are already on the Bundle Select Platform, including Adobe, Visa, Salesforce, Progressive, Perks at Work, and more!

Certification Format: One Live Class offered twice per month

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† None, but driven by eXp agents with corporate and organization connections.

Additional Perks: eXp agents generating accounts earn a 25% referral fee from all business done through the corporations/organizations they bring into Bundle Select.

Additional Requirements: $1000 yearly subscription fee

Making it Rain

Making it Rain leverages the power of digital ads to build a client database for eXp agents that keeps on giving.¬† These ads are designed and placed by eXp‚Äôs expert staff, saving eXp agents time and money.

Certification Format: ¬†On-Demand Courses with prerequisite introductory courses for each lead generation product, each taking 45 minutes to complete.

Preferred Client Qualifications:¬† None

Additional Requirements: eXp agents pay for these cost-effective and affordable ads (they start at just $250 per month).

¬†Realtor Leads Pay at Closing

Aside from ExpressOffers and Making It Rain, all other Revenos programs charge a referral fee at closing for the eXp agent who secures the business. These fees range from 25% to 55%, and they are well worth it for the quality business you gain. Plus, any future referral business you earn from doing a great job is all yours to keep‚Äîno more fees to Revenos.

This is a fantastic opportunity for agents because:

  • Superior Lead Quality: Revenos leads are nothing like the 25% ‚Äì 40% fees you pay to Realtor.com for Opcity leads, which are often low quality and rarely close. With Revenos, you’re investing in high-quality leads that convert.
  • Top Agent Pay: eXp Realty offers some of the highest agent pay in the real estate industry. Top agents can even earn more than 100% of their commission each year. If you’re not familiar with eXp Realty’s pay structure yet, check out our blog ‚Äú2024 Guide to eXp Realty Commission and Fees‚Äù or visit our website at Smart Agent Alliance.

And there you have it.¬† eXp Realty with its Revenos division is the only real estate brokerage company constantly working and succeeding in supplying agents with quality leads. No other brokerage has a lead program like Revenos. That‚Äôs one of the advantages of being an agent at the most profitable brokerage out there, that‚Äôs the most agent-centric brokerage on the planet.

Real Estate Agent Leads That Actually Work‚ÄîOnly at eXp Realty

If you‚Äôre tired of paying top dollar for bottom-barrel leads, you‚Äôre not alone‚Äîand you‚Äôre definitely not stuck. At eXp Realty, the Revenos division flips the script by giving agents access to real estate agent leads that actually convert. These are serious buyers, motivated sellers, corporate relocations, military families, investors, and more‚Äîall matched to eXp agents through smart data and free training.

And this isn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù perk. It‚Äôs a massive career upgrade.

Even better? Agents who join Smart Agent Alliance get extra support to capitalize on it all: Smart Agent Alliance runs meetings, so you gain passive income. How awesome is that? It‚Äôs like free money.¬† Smart Agent Alliance also gives agents access to:

  • A done-for-you and hosted real estate attraction website
  • Social Agent Academy Pro ($10,500 value) for social media marketing
  • Weekly coaching sessions with top producers
  • Customizable lead funnels, email campaigns, and marketing templates
  • And more‚Ä¶

All are free for agents who join through the Smart Agent Alliance sponsor line. Learn more about how eXp Realty and Smart Agent Alliance can help you scale your career. Not sure if eXp is the right fit for you? Take this quick quiz to find out if eXp is a good match, especially if support and systems matter to you. Not sure how passive income grows?¬† You can play with the numbers using our exp realty revenue share calculator to see how much you could earn. Not sure how to become a real estate agent? We‚Äôve got loads of helpful info on that too.

Frequently Asked Questions

How are eXp Realty leads different than other brokerages?

eXp Realty is the only brokerage with a full-time dedicated real estate agent leads division, Revenos. The skilled team leverages eXp Realty’s extensive network to unearth quality leads for eXp Realty agents. In 2024, Revenos provided thousands of top-quality real estate agent leads, generating over $2 billion in closed sales for eXp agents.

Why are eXp Realty‚Äôs Revenos real estate agent leads special?

Revenos does the heavy lifting to find and nurture top-tier lead sources. Revenos digs deep, identifying client characteristics that match them perfectly with an eXp agent. Revenos offers eight distinct programs – ExpressOffers, eXp Affinity, eXp Relocation, eXp Honor Military Rewards, eXp REO (Real Estate Owned), Institutional Investment Services, Bundle Select, and Making It Rain.

How do eXp agents get eXp Realty real estate leads?

Become an eXp agent. Get trained with free Revenos certification courses open to all eXp agents. Gain the standards preferred by Revenos clients. Note that even agents who don‚Äôt meet a client‚Äôs preferred qualifications will at times be the chosen agent.

title: Real vs KW: Which Brokerage is Best for Realtors in 2025?
excerpt: When deciding between Real Broker and Keller Williams (KW), agents must weigh differences in commission splits, fees, training, and overall agent support. This comparison highlights…
content:
When deciding between Real Broker and Keller Williams (KW), agents must weigh differences in commission splits, fees, training, and overall agent support. This comparison highlights key factors to help you determine which brokerage aligns best with your career objectives.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Real vs KW
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

Real Broker provides agents with a highly competitive commission split structure, offering 85/15 to 100/0 splits, with no franchise or royalty fees. Real Broker also has a production cap set at $12K, meaning once agents hit this cap, they keep 100% of their commissions. Furthermore, top producers can qualify for a $24K bonus, which significantly boosts their earning potential. The annual fees are a flat $750 per year, and there are no transaction fees until the cap is reached.

KW (Keller Williams), in contrast, offers commission splits starting at 70/30 and going up to 100/0, depending on the office location. However, agents are required to pay a 6% franchise fee until they reach the cap, which impacts their overall earnings. KW’s production cap varies between $21K and $30K, depending on the market center, which is higher than Real Broker‚Äôs cap. Monthly fees at KW also vary based on the office, and transaction fees are generally included within the royalty fee structure.

Income Opportunities

One area where Real Broker shines is through its revenue share program, which allows agents to earn passive income by recruiting new agents to the brokerage. This revenue-sharing opportunity creates an additional income stream for agents interested in building a team. Real Broker also offers both retirement income and willable income options, providing long-term financial stability.

KW also offers a revenue share model, often referred to as “profit share,” which rewards agents for recruiting others. However, KW does not offer retirement income or willable income paths, which limits some of the long-term financial planning options that Real Broker provides.

Training and Support

Real Broker stands out with its extensive training options, providing over 30 live training sessions each week. These sessions cover topics ranging from lead generation to transaction management, ensuring agents are equipped to succeed. Additionally, Real Broker offers 24/7 agent support, which is critical for agents who need real-time help or guidance during transactions.

KW is well-known for its comprehensive training programs, which are widely regarded as some of the best in the industry. The KW University platform provides agents with various training modules to enhance their skills. However, unlike Real Broker, KW does not provide 24/7 support, which could be a limitation for agents who need assistance outside of regular business hours.

Technology and Resources

Real Broker provides its agents with an advanced, cloud-based system that integrates CRM, marketing platforms, and transaction management tools seamlessly. This streamlined technology stack makes it easier for agents to manage leads and grow their businesses.

KW also offers a solid technology platform through its proprietary Command system, designed to help agents track leads, manage transactions, and create marketing campaigns. While KW has invested heavily in its tech, some agents report challenges with its functionality compared to Real Broker‚Äôs more straightforward, cloud-based tools.

Agent Satisfaction

Real Broker has a Glassdoor rating of 4.5 stars based on 109 reviews, with agents praising its transparency in fees, multiple income streams, and excellent support systems.

KW holds a 4.3-star rating from 7.9K reviews. Many agents appreciate the comprehensive training and the brand‚Äôs established reputation but have expressed concerns about the higher fees and office-based variations in support.

Final Thoughts on Real vs KW

For agents seeking a modern, cloud-based brokerage with lower fees, a lower production cap, and robust income opportunities, Real Broker is an excellent choice. The added benefit of 24/7 support and multiple revenue streams make it a top contender for agents looking for flexibility and long-term career growth.

KW offers strong training programs and a well-known brand, but higher fees and the lack of some income opportunities may make it less appealing for agents looking to maximize their earnings and wealth-building potential.

If you‚Äôd like to explore further, check out our eXp vs traditional brokerage comparison and online brokerage comparison pages to dive deeper into how these brokerages compare. Also, don‚Äôt miss out on reviewing eXp Realty, a brokerage that takes income opportunities and agent support to the next level.

Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Join the leading force in real estate with eXp Realty ‚Äì the only profitable publicly traded brokerage over the past five years and holds the prestigious title of the best brokerage to work for. The benefits of eXp Realty are unmatched and will truly exceed your expectations!

When you join us at Smart Agent Alliance, you‚Äôll also be part of the Wolf Pack at eXp Realty.¬† Together we are one big team and we provide more FREE value than you‚Äôll get anywhere else in the real estate business.

What‚Äôs included? Access our exclusive SAA Vault Assets to enhance your business efficiency, attend weekly team video calls filled with invaluable insights and top agent strategies, and receive the Social Agent Academy Program and Investor Army Courses ‚Äì a combined value of over $1,500 ‚Äì absolutely free. And that‚Äôs just the beginning! Explore more about our robust team benefits.

Don‚Äôt let this opportunity pass you by. Transform your real estate career, maximize your income, and secure your future. Contact us now to schedule a video consultation or email us at team@SmartAgentAlliance.com. We‚Äôre here to ensure your success.

title: Real Estate Agent Expenses New Agents Should Expect in 2025
excerpt: So, you‚Äôre thinking about becoming a real estate agent? It‚Äôs an exciting career with plenty of potential, but let‚Äôs get real‚Äîit comes with its own…
content:
So, you‚Äôre thinking about becoming a real estate agent? It‚Äôs an exciting career with plenty of potential, but let‚Äôs get real‚Äîit comes with its own set of costs. From licensing fees to marketing yourself, it may feel like everyone‚Äôs got a hand in your wallet.

But don‚Äôt worry, this isn‚Äôt about scaring you off. It‚Äôs about prepping you so those real estate agent expenses don‚Äôt sneak up and burn a hole through your bank account. After all, launching a real estate career is like starting your own business, and that means start-up costs and ongoing expenses.

The good news? Many of these are tax-deductible, and with the right planning, you‚Äôll be ready to handle them like a pro. Let‚Äôs break it all down so you can hit the ground running without feeling overwhelmed. Here‚Äôs your handy dandy index:

Licensing Costs
Brokerage fees?
Professional Fees?
Operational Expenses
Listing Expenses?
Lead Generation Expenses
Professional Development Fees?
Financial Planning
That‚Äôs a Wrap
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty
Frequently Asked Questions

Licensing Costs

To kick off your real estate career, you‚Äôll need to navigate a series of licensing costs, and while they may seem small at first glance, they can stack up quickly. First up, you‚Äôve got the pre-licensing course, which typically costs between $150 and $1,000, depending on your state and whether you opt for online or in-person classes.

Study guides, which make prepping for your exam easier, can add another $35 to your expenses. Then there‚Äôs the state exam fee itself, usually around $100 to $400, plus the background check, which runs anywhere from $22 to $100 depending on where you live.

Once you pass the exam, you‚Äôll need to pay a fee to obtain your real estate license‚Äîanywhere from $150 to $350. But don‚Äôt forget, some states also require post-licensing education to keep your license active, which can range from $50 to $450.

All in all, getting your real estate license will likely cost you between $500 and $1,500, depending on your state and choices. For more exact information on the licensing process and fees in your state check out more information here. https://wp.saabuildingblocks.com/staging/how-to-get-a-real-estate-license/

Brokerage fees

Once you have your real estate license, the next step is joining a brokerage, and with that comes a whole new set of real estate agent expenses. First off, there‚Äôs the commission split‚Äîthis is where the brokerage takes a percentage of your earnings. Splits can vary widely, mostly in the range from a generous 90/10 split to a heftier 50/50, which can make a big difference in your take-home pay.

On top of that, many brokerages charge an initial start-up fee, usually around $50 – $150, just for joining. After that, you‚Äôll likely be paying monthly fees or annual fees. These range from about $85 to thousands per month, which covers the brokerage‚Äôs ongoing support, office space, tech platforms, tools, and resources.

Then, there’s Errors & Omissions (E&O) insurance, a necessary protection against potential lawsuits, which typically costs anywhere from $60 per transaction to $2200 upfront before you have any deals. So, yes, this is a big one to know the exact amount.

All these real estate agent expenses vary wildly between brokerages. To get more thorough information on brokerage splits and fees check out our brokerage comparison tool here.

Overall, these expenses can add up quickly, so it‚Äôs essential to compare brokerages and to know what brokerages offer in return, whether it‚Äôs resources, training, or marketing materials.

Professional Fees

Once you‚Äôve joined a brokerage, there are some additional professional fees to consider. One of the most common is the cost of joining the National Association of REALTORS¬Æ (NAR), which can be a great boost to your career.

While not always mandatory, NAR membership gives you access to valuable tools like marketing guidance, tech solutions, exclusive discounts, and a network of over a million associates. Membership also offers you the prestigious REALTOR¬Æ designation, which can elevate your credibility. NAR dues are around $150 per year. https://www.nar.realtor/membership/dues-information

State and local real estate boards may also charge a few hundred dollars or more annually for membership. On top of that, there are MLS (Multiple Listing Service) fees, which run about $150 to $500 per year. The MLS is essential for real estate agents as it gives you access to property listings, making it a must-have for anyone serious about their real estate career.

Operational Expenses

When it comes to operational real estate agent expenses, things can add up quickly in your real estate career. One of the first expenses you‚Äôll need to consider is building and maintaining a website, which can cost anywhere from $180 to $3,480 per year, depending on how fancy you want it to be.

Other website options can be to use a personal website that your brokerage offers. For example, eXp Realty agents get a personal IDX website (more than a page on the brokerage website) that is part of their $85 monthly fee. That helps keep costs down!

Then there are the business cards‚Äîaround $500 a year for a memorable design that leaves an impression. Plus, promotional items like branded pens or magnets can keep your name in front of clients, helping you stay top of mind for future business.

Also don‚Äôt forget about travel expenses, especially since real estate agents are always on the move. Expect to pay at least $2,000 a year on gas, car maintenance, insurance, and maybe even the occasional plane ticket if you‚Äôre attending national conferences.

If you work from home, office expenses like internet, paper, and pens will add up to about $2,400 per year. Plus, you‚Äôll need a reliable printer and scanner to keep your documents in check.

Health insurance is another biggie, costing roughly $450 per month for individuals and more for families. However, again, large brokerages like eXp Realty that leverage their size and influence have access to much lower-cost healthcare options for individuals and families. More about that here.

And there are more operational real estate agent expenses. There are transaction coordinators to help with deal paperwork likely costing from $300 – $700 per transaction.

Even small costs like lockbox keys (about $15-$25 a month), and all-important client lunches and gifts ($25-$150 a month) can make a dent. But remember, these tools and services keep your real estate business running smoothly, so it‚Äôs smart to budget for them upfront!

Listing Expenses

When it comes to listing expenses, they can stack up quickly, but they‚Äôre key to making your properties stand out and attracting potential buyers.

First off, you‚Äôll want to invest in real estate signs, which typically run between $50 and $150 per sign. You‚Äôll also need lockboxes for your listings, usually around $100 each, to keep the property secure during showings.

Hiring professional photographers or videographers is crucial to showcase the home‚Äôs best features online, with costs ranging from $100 to $500 per listing.

You also may need 2D or 3D floor plans, single property websites, drone shots, and 3D walkthroughs. Expect to tack on $500 to $1500 more here. And if you‚Äôre listing luxury properties, expect these costs to be closer to $5000.

Printing listing flyers adds another $50 – $300 to your expenses while promoting the listing through social media ads or classifieds could cost anywhere from $100 to thousands.

When it comes to open houses, you‚Äôll need to budget for snacks, drinks, and other refreshments to make the experience inviting, typically costing $50 to $250 per open house.

If you really want to go the extra mile, and if it‚Äôs economically feasible, consider staging the home, which can lead to faster sales and higher prices, making it a worthy investment.

All in all, listing-related expenses for each listing can range from $1,000 to multi-thousands annually, depending on how you choose to market the property. It‚Äôs these extra touches that can make a big difference in how quickly and successfully you close deals. And, that‚Äôs what you want – a payday to refund you for all your expenses!

Lead Generation Expenses

When it comes to generating leads, real estate agent expenses can add up, but they‚Äôre crucial for growing your business. Advertising your services is one of the biggest investments, with most agent‚Äôs costs ranging from $1,000 to $10,000 annually or more!

In your first year, marketing will likely take a big chunk of your budget. You‚Äôll either pay for it upfront or invest your blood, sweat, and tears with low-cost methods such as door-knocking, calling FSBOs, or creating organic social media accounts and YouTube channels. üôÇ

On top your actual advertising, you‚Äôll need a process to keep your leads and communication with them all organized. You‚Äôll need a CRM – customer relationship management tool – to accomplish that. CRMS can cost $1000, $3000, or even more. But some brokerages, like eXp Realty, include top-end CRMs as part of their agent fee package without additional agent expense.

While advertising significantly adds to your real estate agent expenses, it increases your visibility and provides prospects for you to convert to deal-closing clients!

Professional Development Fees

Staying sharp in real estate means ongoing learning, and that comes with a price tag. Continuing education (CE) courses are essential for agents who want to keep their licenses and thrive in a competitive market. On average, agents spend around $200 per year on these courses, but costs vary by state.

Beyond the basic requirements, agents often take classes to earn certifications and gain designations to boost their expertise and credibility. These investments enhance skills and open doors to new client opportunities and specialized niches. Costs range from hundreds to thousands.

Networking events are another real estate agent expense, allowing agents to meet new people, exchange ideas, and grow their businesses. Sometimes, these events require travel and accommodations, adding to the cost, but the payoff in connections and potential clients makes it worthwhile.

Hosting your own events can also be a smart investment, giving you a platform to stand out and expand your network in the real estate world.

Financial Planning

When you’re a real estate agent, financial planning is a must, especially since most agents are classified as independent contractors. This means you‚Äôre responsible for covering self-employment taxes, which include both Medicare and Social Security‚Äîthe costs that a typical employer would handle.

But don‚Äôt worry; there are perks too! Many work-related expenses, like gas, office supplies, and even marketing costs, can be claimed as tax deductions. Keeping track of these deductions helps offset the self-employment tax burden.

It‚Äôs also important to budget for quarterly tax payments to avoid a hefty bill at the end of the year. Agents should also work closely with a tax professional who can ensure they‚Äôre taking advantage of all possible deductions, making tax time smoother and more financially beneficial.

That‚Äôs a Wrap

Becoming a real estate agent comes with exciting opportunities, but it carries significant real estate agent expenses. From licensing and brokerage fees to ongoing expenses, agents face a variety of costs that can add up quickly.

However, you can manage these expenses effectively while building a successful and lucrative career. Understanding these financial commitments upfront will help you stay ahead and thrive in the competitive world of real estate.

Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

By partnering with us, you‚Äôll be joining the ONLY profitable public brokerage in the past 5 years that agents rank as the best brokerage to work for.

With Smart Agent Alliance you‚Äôll enjoy personalized day-to-day concierge care plus assets like customizable agent presentations, business automation, production checklists, customizable social media posts, and so much more.

As a member of our team, you‚Äôll also enjoy exclusive access to the Wolf Pack weekly webinars, Social Agent Academy for social media training, the Wolf Pack Hub for easy onboarding, Investor Army for investing and flipping houses training, and more.

Don‚Äôt miss out on this amazing opportunity to maximize your earnings and build a thriving agent business. Join eXp Realty today and experience unparalleled support from our FREE team.

Not quite convinced? No problem! Contact us to set up a meeting, request a link to a live webinar, and/or get all your questions answered via email, phone call, or video call. We‚Äôre here to help you succeed!

For more information, check out our eXp Realty overview, learn about our team benefits, and visit our Join Smart Agent Alliance page. Partner with us today and take your agent career to the next level!

Frequently Asked Questions

  • What are the typical start-up costs to become a real estate agent?
  • What brokerage fees will new real estate agents pay?
  • Regarding real estate agent expenses – what are the usual professional fees?
  • What operational expenses can real estate agents expect?
  • What do real estate agents pay for listing expenses?
  • What lead generation expenses do real estate agents have?
  • What professional development fees do real estate agents have?

What are the typical start-up costs to become a real estate agent?

Those include a pre-licensing course, study guides, state exam fee, background check, real estate license fee and later post-licensing education to keep your license active. All in all, these likely add up to between $500 and $1,500 depending on your state and choices. Find more information here.

What brokerage fees will new real estate agents pay?

First off, there‚Äôs the commission split that usually ranges from a 90/10 split to a heftier 50/50. Many brokerages charge an initial start-up fee, and monthly fees or annual fees. Then, there’s Errors & Omissions (E&O) insurance. To get more thorough information on brokerage splits and fees check out our brokerage comparison tool here.

Regarding real estate agent expenses – what are the usual professional fees?

One of the most common is the cost of joining the National Association of REALTORS¬Æ (NAR), which is not always mandatory. State and local real estate boards may also charge a few hundred dollars or more annually for membership. On top of that, there are MLS (Multiple Listing Service) fees, which run about $150 to $500 per year.

What operational expenses can real estate agents expect?

There are numerous expenses such as building and maintaining a website, business cards, promotional items, travel expenses, gas, car maintenance, insurance, and maybe even the occasional plane ticket, office expenses like internet, paper, pens, printer and scanner. Also, health insurance (More about eXp Realty‚Äôs Healthcare here), transaction coordinators, lockbox keys, and client lunches and gifts.

What do real estate agents pay for listing expenses?

Listing agents often pay for real estate signs, professional photographers or videographers, 2D or 3D floor plans, single property websites, drone shots, 3D walkthroughs, printed listing flyers, open houses refreshments, sometimes staging, assistants and transaction coordinators.

What lead generation expenses do real estate agents have?

Advertising services is one of the biggest investments. Agents can invest heavily in magazine ads and neighborhood mailers or they can use their blood, sweat, and tears to door-knock, call expired listings and FSBOs, or seek organic social media and YouTube leads. Agents also need a CRM – customer relationship management tool – to accomplish lead organization.

What professional development fees do real estate agents have?

Continuing education (CE) courses are essential for agents who want to keep their licenses and thrive in a competitive market. Plus. agents often take classes to earn certifications and gain designations to boost their expertise and credibility. Networking events are another real estate agent expense, allowing agents to meet new people, exchange ideas, and grow their businesses.
metaDescription: Explore Real Estate Agent Expenses, from licensing fees to marketing costs, and learn how to budget for a successful career in real estate.

title: Fathom vs Corcoran: Which Brokerage is Best for Realtors?
excerpt: If you're a real estate agent evaluating your next move, this comparison between Fathom Realty and Corcoran lays out exactly what you need to know.…
content:
If you’re a real estate agent evaluating your next move, this comparison between Fathom Realty and Corcoran lays out exactly what you need to know. These brokerages operate with fundamentally different approaches when it comes to commission, support, technology, and overall agent experience. Whether you’re trying to keep more of your money or build prestige in luxury markets, here’s how they stack up.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Fathom vs. Corcoran
Why Smart Agent Alliance Agents Thrive at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

Fathom Realty offers a 100/0 commission split, meaning agents keep every dollar of commission they earn. There are no franchise or royalty fees, and the only out-of-pocket costs are a flat $700 per year and per-transaction fees between $150 and $250. This ultra-simple structure is ideal for agents who want to calculate their take-home pay without mental gymnastics.

Corcoran takes the opposite approach. Commission splits range from 50/50 to 70/30, and agents also pay a 6% franchise fee on every transaction. There‚Äôs no production cap, which means that even top-producing agents continue to split commissions and pay fees indefinitely. Transaction fees are wrapped into that structure, but Corcoran also charges separate costs for E&O insurance‚Äîoften on the higher end. Monthly office fees vary by location, adding more inconsistency to an agent‚Äôs cost structure.

If your goal is maximizing profit, Fathom offers clarity and savings. Corcoran, while built for luxury branding, definitely takes a bigger cut.

Income Opportunities

Fathom Realty is strictly transactional. There‚Äôs no revenue share, no stock awards, and no pathway to earn retirement or willable income through the company. You earn what you sell‚Äîfull stop. That‚Äôs great if you‚Äôre focused on commissions today but offers no passive income potential for the future.

Corcoran operates similarly. There are no residual income paths, equity awards, or wealth-building opportunities beyond traditional sales. Like Fathom, you sell, you earn, and that‚Äôs where the income stops.

Neither brokerage supports agents in building long-term financial freedom. If you want your income to grow beyond what you personally produce, you‚Äôll have to look elsewhere.

Training and Support

Fathom Realty keeps things lean, which means there‚Äôs no formal in-house training and no around-the-clock agent support. This model works well for seasoned agents who are already operating independently, but may leave newer agents feeling a little stranded.

Corcoran does provide training, but the quality and structure vary significantly depending on the local office. There’s no universal system, and like Fathom, there‚Äôs no 24/7 support, so you‚Äôre dependent on office availability and manager responsiveness. It‚Äôs workable if you’re in a high-performing office, but it’s inconsistent across the board.

For both brokerages, self-motivation is a must. You won‚Äôt find structured national programs or on-demand mentorship platforms here.

Technology and Resources

Fathom Realty offers a tech platform that covers the basics‚Äîtransaction management, client communication, and compliance tools. It gets the job done, but it‚Äôs not designed to impress. If you want cutting-edge marketing automation, AI-powered CRMs, or integrated branding systems, you‚Äôll need to add your own tools or join a team that provides them.

Corcoran, with its luxury real estate focus, does provide high-end marketing resources. Presentation matters here, and the materials reflect that. Their technology isn‚Äôt necessarily more advanced, but it‚Äôs geared toward the polished look and feel expected in luxury markets. Still, it‚Äôs not a cloud-based platform and doesn‚Äôt offer the kind of flexibility or innovation you‚Äôll find with more modern models.

In short, Fathom gives you the freedom to build with lean tools. Corcoran provides stronger branding, but the tech behind it may not evolve as fast as today‚Äôs most scalable brokerages.

Agent Satisfaction

Fathom Realty has earned a solid 4.6-star rating from hundreds of agent reviews on Glassdoor. Agents regularly praise the simplicity of the model and the ability to keep more of their income. Common frustrations center around the lack of training and the self-reliance required to succeed.

Corcoran comes in slightly behind with a 4.4-star rating. Agents often speak highly of the company‚Äôs luxury brand and marketing support but also note concerns about high fees and commission splits that chip away at earnings. Again, office-by-office experiences vary, and that inconsistency shows up in the reviews.

Both brokerages have their loyal fans‚Äîbut the financial structure at Fathom tends to generate more consistent praise.

Final Thoughts on Fathom vs. Corcoran

Fathom Realty is a match for agents who want to maximize their commission, eliminate unnecessary fees, and run their business without extra layers. It‚Äôs not for agents who need hand-holding or crave the cachet of a big-name brand, but it‚Äôs built for independence and profitability.

Corcoran is a fit for agents committed to the luxury space who value strong marketing assets and a prestigious brand. However, you‚Äôll pay for that brand recognition through lower splits and higher fees‚Äîand you won‚Äôt get much in return when it comes to wealth-building options or passive income.

If you‚Äôre just comparing these two, the question becomes: do you want to be branded or be profitable?

Why Smart Agent Alliance Agents Thrive at eXp Realty

Our team at Smart Agent Alliance is built for agents who want to:

  1. Keep More Money: Retain up to¬†100% of commissions¬†after cap, with no hidden fees.
  2. Build Beyond Themselves: Earn¬†revenue share¬†from your team and stock grants for hitting goals.
  3. Access Turnkey Systems: From done-for-you lead generation funnels to weekly masterminds with 7-figure agents.

We don‚Äôt believe in ‚Äúone-size-fits-all‚Äù real estate. That‚Äôs why we provide free, customizable tools to help you scale your way, whether you‚Äôre a solo agent or building a mega-team.

title: Fathom vs Better Homes: Which is Best for Realtors?
excerpt: This isn‚Äôt just another brokerage comparison ‚Äî it‚Äôs a real look at how your paycheck, support, and business tools will be affected by your choice.…
content:
This isn‚Äôt just another brokerage comparison ‚Äî it‚Äôs a real look at how your paycheck, support, and business tools will be affected by your choice. Whether you’re drawn to the simplicity of flat fees or the prestige of a well-known name, here’s how Fathom Realty and Better Homes & Gardens Real Estate compare where it counts.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Fathom vs. Better Homes & Gardens
Why Smart Agent Alliance Agents Thrive at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

At Fathom Realty, the 100/0 commission split means what it says ‚Äî agents keep every cent of their commission. There are no franchise or royalty fees taking a cut, and agents enjoy complete freedom from production caps. The only recurring costs are a flat $700 annual fee and a per-transaction fee between $150 and $250. This predictable, no-frills model has been one of Fathom‚Äôs biggest selling points for agents who want to simplify their finances and scale their business without penalty.

Better Homes & Gardens, in contrast, operates under a traditional split model that ranges from 60/40 to 80/20. The company also takes a 6% franchise or royalty fee, which further trims the agent‚Äôs net income. There‚Äôs no cap in place, so even top producers continue paying the split. Monthly fees vary based on office and region, and while transaction fees are baked into the royalty structure, there are additional costs like E&O insurance. Overall, it‚Äôs a higher-cost model, even though it comes with the familiarity of a household brand.

If your goal is to keep more of what you earn, Fathom’s lean model clearly gives you more breathing room.

Income Opportunities

Fathom Realty doesn‚Äôt offer revenue share, equity awards, or retirement paths ‚Äî it‚Äôs a commission-only setup. What you close is what you make, and that‚Äôs where it ends. It‚Äôs clean and simple, but there‚Äôs no added value for long-term wealth building.

Better Homes & Gardens follows the same philosophy. Agents earn their commission and have no access to recurring income, revenue sharing, or other wealth-building incentives. So while the company supports sales activity with its branding, it doesn‚Äôt reward agents beyond the deals they personally close.

Neither model offers additional income streams, which may work fine for those focused only on transactions, but won‚Äôt meet the needs of agents thinking about scaling or exiting the business someday.

Training and Support

Fathom Realty has earned a reputation for being agent-friendly, but it doesn‚Äôt provide structured training or 24/7 support. That approach works well for confident, experienced agents who already know the ropes, but may feel limiting to newer agents seeking mentorship or coaching. The low overhead and minimal intrusion are perks for self-starters, but not ideal for someone who needs handholding.

Better Homes & Gardens does offer training, but it varies by office. Some locations are known for robust support and onboarding, while others offer the bare minimum. Like Fathom, there‚Äôs no 24/7 support, so agents are largely dependent on local managers and office culture for help.

In both models, success depends heavily on your own initiative and your specific office environment.

Technology and Resources

Fathom Realty gives agents access to basic tech tools like transaction management systems and CRMs. It‚Äôs not flashy, but it gets the job done. There‚Äôs no massive tech suite, and agents who want advanced lead generation or marketing platforms will need to build that stack independently or join a team that offers it.

Better Homes & Gardens leans into technology and branding more heavily. With the backing of a recognizable brand, agents can access strong marketing resources and CRM systems designed to support high visibility and lead follow-up. These tools can be especially useful for agents who are less tech-savvy or who want to plug into a ready-made system.

Fathom provides the essentials with freedom to customize. Better Homes & Gardens offers a more fully built platform, but it comes at a higher cost.

Agent Satisfaction

Fathom Realty currently holds a 4.6-star rating on Glassdoor, with hundreds of agents praising the simple commission structure, predictable fees, and freedom to operate independently. Agents regularly mention financial clarity as one of the biggest advantages.

Better Homes & Gardens earns a slightly lower rating of 4.3 stars from fewer total reviews. Agents tend to appreciate the branding, marketing tools, and name recognition, but also mention the pain of ongoing fees and limited income options as recurring downsides.

If agent reviews are any indicator, the satisfaction difference often comes down to expectations ‚Äî whether agents prioritize branding or bottom-line income.

Final Thoughts on Fathom vs. Better Homes & Gardens

Fathom Realty is the choice for agents who want full commission, fixed fees, and minimal brokerage interference. It‚Äôs best suited for those who value autonomy and know how to manage their business without needing constant support or tech-heavy tools.

Better Homes & Gardens makes more sense for agents who want the credibility of a national brand and access to advanced marketing resources. But it comes with the trade-off of lower commission retention and more ongoing costs, with no cap in sight.

Neither brokerage supports passive income, equity, or long-term wealth strategies. If that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for, you may want to explore an alternative that gives you both earning power and financial growth opportunities.

Why Smart Agent Alliance Agents Thrive at eXp Realty

Our team at Smart Agent Alliance is built for agents who want to:

    1. Keep More Money: Retain up to¬†100% of commissions¬†after cap, with no hidden fees.
    2. Build Beyond Themselves: Earn¬†revenue share¬†from your team and stock grants for hitting goals.
    3. Access Turnkey Systems: From done-for-you lead generation funnels to weekly masterminds with 7-figure agents.

We don‚Äôt believe in ‚Äúone-size-fits-all‚Äù real estate. That‚Äôs why we provide free, customizable tools to help you scale your way‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre a solo agent or building a mega-team.

title: LPT vs REMAX: Which Brokerage is Best for Realtors in 2025?
excerpt: In this comparison between LPT vs REMAX, we'll dive into the key aspects that agents should consider, including commission structures, fees, income opportunities, and agent…
content:
In this comparison between LPT vs REMAX, we’ll dive into the key aspects that agents should consider, including commission structures, fees, income opportunities, and agent support.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on LPT¬† vs REMAX
Join Our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

LPT Realty offers commission splits ranging from 80/20 to 100/0. This flexibility allows agents to maximize their earnings. There are no franchise or royalty fees, making it more cost-effective for agents who want to keep a higher percentage of their commissions. The production cap at LPT Realty is $15K, meaning agents keep 100% of their commissions after hitting this cap. Monthly fees vary, with options as low as $500/year plus $0 or $89/month, or $149/month, depending on the agent’s choice. Transaction fees are $195 before reaching the cap.

In contrast, RE/MAX has commission splits that start at 60/40 and go up to 95/5. However, RE/MAX charges a 5% franchise/royalty fee, which reduces agents’ take-home earnings. The production cap is significantly higher at $23K, and monthly fees range from $300 to $2,500, making RE/MAX a more costly option for agents. Transaction fees are included in the royalty fees, which may provide some predictability, but the higher fees overall can reduce the agent‚Äôs bottom line.

Income Opportunities

LPT Realty stands out by offering a revenue share program, allowing agents to earn additional income through team building and recruitment. This offers an extra stream of passive income beyond commissions. LPT also provides retirement income and willable income paths, offering agents a long-term financial security option.

RE/MAX, on the other hand, does not offer a revenue share program, nor does it provide retirement or willable income paths. Agents at RE/MAX rely solely on their commission-based income, which may limit long-term financial planning options.

Training and Support

LPT Realty does not have a specified formal training program but offers 24/7 agent support, ensuring that agents have access to help when needed. This level of support is crucial for agents who prefer having consistent access to resources and guidance.

RE/MAX provides access to its Online University for training, which is a structured learning platform. However, it lacks 24/7 support, which may be a downside for agents who need more immediate assistance, particularly in fast-paced markets.

Technology and Resources

LPT Realty provides agents with access to a variety of technology tools and platforms designed to enhance their marketing and client management efforts. The cloud-based model allows for flexibility and efficiency, especially for agents on the go.

RE/MAX also invests in technology, offering agents tools for lead management, marketing, and transaction handling. However, the higher cost structure may make these tools less attractive compared to LPT Realty‚Äôs more affordable options.

Agent Satisfaction

LPT Realty has a 4.3-star rating on Glassdoor, with 37 reviews. Agents appreciate the flexibility in commission splits, lower fees, and income opportunities through the revenue share model.

RE/MAX holds a 4.2-star rating from 3.3K reviews. While the brand recognition and vast network are major benefits, agents often mention the high fees as a downside.

Final Thoughts on LPT vs REMAX

LPT Realty offers more flexibility with commission splits, lower fees, and additional income streams through its revenue share program, retirement income path, and willable income options. This makes it a great choice for agents who want to maximize their income potential while keeping their costs low.

RE/MAX, on the other hand, is a well-established brand with strong name recognition and a large network, but its higher fees and lack of additional income opportunities may make it less attractive for agents focused on long-term financial growth.

For more in-depth comparisons, check out our¬†eXp vs traditional brokerage comparison¬†and¬†online brokerage comparison¬†pages. Explore the advantages each brokerage offers, and don‚Äôt forget to see why many agents are turning to¬†eXp Realty¬†for even more opportunities.

Join Our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Join the leading force in real estate with eXp Realty ‚Äì the only profitable publicly traded brokerage over the past five years and holds the prestigious title of the best brokerage to work for. The benefits of eXp Realty are unmatched and will truly exceed your expectations!

When you join us at Smart Agent Alliance, you‚Äôll also be part of the Wolf Pack at eXp Realty.¬† Together we are one big team and we provide more FREE value than you‚Äôll get anywhere else in the real estate business.

What‚Äôs included? Access our exclusive SAA Vault Assets to enhance your business efficiency, attend weekly team video calls filled with invaluable insights and top agent strategies, and receive the Social Agent Academy Program and Investor Army Courses ‚Äì a combined value of over $1,500 ‚Äì absolutely free. And that‚Äôs just the beginning! Explore more about our robust team benefits.

Don‚Äôt let this opportunity pass you by. Transform your real estate career, maximize your income, and secure your future. Contact us now to schedule a video consultation or email us at team@SmartAgentAlliance.com. We‚Äôre here to ensure your success.

title: LPT vs Compass: Which is Best for Realtors?
excerpt: In this comparison between LPT¬† vs Compass, we‚Äôll dive into the key differences that real estate agents should consider when choosing the best brokerage to…
content:
In this comparison between LPT¬† vs Compass, we‚Äôll dive into the key differences that real estate agents should consider when choosing the best brokerage to meet their career and income goals.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on LPT Realty vs Compass
Join Our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

LPT Realty offers competitive commission splits ranging from 80/20 to 100/0, with no franchise or royalty fees. Agents benefit from a $15K production cap, after which they retain 100% of their commission. LPT Realty‚Äôs monthly fees are flexible, starting at $0 and going up to $149, depending on the agent‚Äôs package. Transaction fees are set at $195 before the cap, making it a cost-efficient option for agents looking to maximize earnings.

Compass, in contrast, has commission splits that range from 60/40 to 92.5/7.5, however, Compassagents only sometimes have a production cap, meaning agents continue to split commissions indefinitely. Monthly fees start at $145 and can vary depending on the office, and transaction fees may go up to 4%, making it a more costly option.

Income Opportunities

LPT Realty offers a revenue share model, allowing agents to generate passive income by recruiting others to the brokerage. This program creates additional long-term income opportunities for agents. LPT Realty also offers a retirement income path and willable income, ensuring agents can plan for their financial future beyond commissions.

Compass does not offer a revenue share model, retirement income, or willable income paths. Agents at Compass are limited to commission-based income, which can restrict long-term financial growth and wealth-building potential.

Training and Support

LPT Realty provides agents with solid training resources and 24/7 agent support, ensuring agents have the tools they need to succeed at any time. The availability of support round-the-clock is a key advantage for agents who need immediate assistance.

Compass has a more traditional training approach through the Compass Academy, offering good resources but without 24/7 agent support. This can be a downside for agents who require ongoing support, especially during non-standard working hours.

Technology and Resources

LPT Realty provides advanced technology platforms that support CRM, marketing, and transaction management, giving agents the flexibility and efficiency needed to thrive in modern real estate. These tools are cloud-based, allowing agents to access their work anytime, anywhere.

Compass is known for its proprietary technology, which is geared toward marketing and luxury markets. While it is highly regarded, the higher costs associated with accessing these tools may deter some agents from looking for a more affordable option.

Agent Satisfaction

LPT Realty has a Glassdoor rating of 4.3 stars from 37 reviews, with agents praising the revenue share program and lower fees. The smaller number of reviews reflects LPT Realty‚Äôs newer entry into the market, but feedback is generally positive.

Compass holds a 3.7-star rating from 2.4K reviews. While its prestige and technology are appreciated, many agents express concerns over the higher fees and the lack of income opportunities beyond commissions.

Final Thoughts on LPT Realty vs Compass

LPT Realty stands out with its lower fees, income opportunities through revenue sharing, and long-term financial benefits like retirement and willable income paths. It is a great option for agents looking for cost-effective solutions and passive income streams.

Compass is a prestigious brokerage with strong branding and luxury market expertise, but its higher costs and lack of passive income options may not appeal to agents focused on maximizing earnings and planning for the future.

title: Real vs Compass: Which Brokerage is Best for Realtors in 2025?
excerpt: Choosing between Real (also known as Real Broker) and Compass is a crucial decision for any real estate agent looking to build a successful career.…
content:
Choosing between Real (also known as Real Broker) and Compass is a crucial decision for any real estate agent looking to build a successful career. This article will break down the key differences in commission splits, fees, training, technology, and overall agent satisfaction to help you determine which brokerage better aligns with your goals.

Commission Splits and Fees
Income Opportunities
Training and Support
Technology and Resources
Agent Satisfaction
Final Thoughts on Real vs Compass
Join Our FREE Team at eXp Realty

Commission Splits and Fees

Real Broker offers highly competitive commission splits ranging from 85/15 to 100/0, with no franchise or royalty fees, making it a top choice for agents wanting to maximize their earnings. Real Broker also has a production cap of $12K, meaning that agents keep 100% of their commissions once they hit this cap. The brokerage also rewards top agents with a $24K bonus, making it appealing for high producers. Monthly fees are $750 per year, with no transaction fees until agents reach the cap.

Compass, on the other hand, offers commission splits from 60/40 to 92.5/7.5, but agents must pay a 4% marketing fee, which can make a significant cut into their overall earnings. Additionally, Compass only sometimes offers a production cap or top agent bonuses, which can be a drawback for high-earning agents. Monthly fees vary by office but typically start at $145.

Income Opportunities

One of the standout features of Real Broker is its revenue share model, which allows agents to earn income by recruiting other agents. This provides an additional income stream that goes beyond commissions. Real Broker also offers retirement income and willable income paths for agents who meet the time qualifications, giving them long-term financial security.

In contrast, Compass does not offer a revenue share program or additional income opportunities like retirement income or willable income. Agents at Compass are primarily dependent on their commission earnings, which may limit long-term wealth-building potential.

Training and Support

Real Broker excels in providing consistent, high-quality training. Agents have access to 30+ live training sessions each week, covering everything from lead generation to transaction management. Additionally, Real offers 24/7 agent support, ensuring that agents can get help whenever they need it.

Compass provides training through its Compass Academy, which is widely recognized for its quality. However, unlike Real Broker, Compass does not offer 24/7 support, which could be a limitation for agents working in fast-paced markets or requiring immediate assistance.

Technology and Resources

Both brokerages offer cutting-edge technology to help agents succeed. Real Broker uses cloud-based systems that integrate CRM tools, marketing platforms, and transaction management, making it highly efficient for tech-savvy agents. Compass, on the other hand, is known for its proprietary technology platform, which includes marketing, listing tools, and data-driven insights to help agents stand out. However, Compass‚Äôs tech offerings come at a higher cost, which could impact an agent‚Äôs profitability.

Agent Satisfaction

Real Broker has an impressive Glassdoor rating of 4.5 stars from 109 reviews. Agents at Real frequently praise the transparent fee structure, income opportunities, and the level of training and support offered.

Compass holds a 3.7-star rating from 2.4K reviews on Glassdoor. While Compass agents appreciate the brand‚Äôs marketing power and tech tools, complaints often arise around the high fees and limited income opportunities beyond commissions.

Final Thoughts on Real vs Compass

For agents looking for a brokerage with lower fees, more income streams, and robust support, Real Broker is the clear winner. The revenue share model, bonus opportunities, and comprehensive training make it a solid choice for agents who want to grow their careers while maximizing their earnings.

Compass offers a well-known brand and excellent technology, but higher fees and fewer income opportunities might make it less attractive for agents focused on long-term wealth-building.

For more in-depth comparisons, check out our eXp vs traditional brokerage comparison and online brokerage comparison pages. Explore the advantages each brokerage offers, and don‚Äôt forget to see why many agents are turning to eXp Realty for even more opportunities.

When you join us at Smart Agent Alliance, you‚Äôll also be part of the Wolf Pack at eXp Realty.¬† Together we are one big team and we provide more FREE value than you‚Äôll get anywhere else in the real estate business.

What‚Äôs included? Access our exclusive SAA Vault Assets to enhance your business efficiency, attend weekly team video calls filled with invaluable insights and top agent strategies, and receive the Social Agent Academy Program and Investor Army Courses ‚Äì a combined value of over $1,500 ‚Äì absolutely free. And that‚Äôs just the beginning! Explore more about our robust team benefits.

Don‚Äôt let this opportunity pass you by. Transform your real estate career, maximize your income, and secure your future. Contact us now to schedule a video consultation or email us at team@SmartAgentAlliance.com. We‚Äôre here to ensure your success.

title: 10 Realtor Questions to Expect from Homebuyers
excerpt: Hey there, real estate buyer agents! With the new NAR changes in place, you might be worried about needing to meet potential home buyers, prove…
content:
Hey there, real estate buyer agents! With the new NAR changes in place, you might be worried about needing to meet potential home buyers, prove your worth, and get signed buyer representation agreements all so you get paid for your work and time

Relax! All you need is some prep on what to expect.¬† This blog fills you in on crucial realtor questions you need to nail and we‚Äôll provide pro tips to seal that client buyer representation agreement. Here‚Äôs your handy dandy index.

As you know, now you must secure signed buyer representation agreements before showing any homes. That buyer representation agreement will lay out the cost of your services.¬† Being upfront with fees means home buyers won‚Äôt sign with just any old agent.¬† You‚Äôll now be expected to convince home buyers of your worth, mostly likely during a client interview‚Ä¶of you, not them!

Agent Background
Education, Experience & Professional Background
Saving Dough for Homebuyers
Steller Reviews
Winning in Multiple Offers
Advising Against Risky Purchases
Brokerage Value
Fees and Discounts
Service Fee Menus
The Real Deal on Commissions
Wrapping it Up
Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty
Frequently Asked Questions

While this interview process may feel new, listing agents have done this for ages‚Äîimpressing home sellers to snag listings. Now, it‚Äôs your turn to step up and dazzle the home buyers.

Remember, throughout your interview, clients will be assessing your demeanor. They‚Äôll be looking for warmth, responsiveness, and professionalism. ¬†Be conscious of your tone and approach. Show that you‚Äôre listening actively, that you‚Äôre invested in understanding their needs, and that you‚Äôre approachable.

Ok, let‚Äôs get into realtor questions you should be prepared to answer during your buyer agent interview with a home buyer.

Agent Background

Expect homebuyers to quiz you about your roots. How long have you been around the area? How well do you know the local quirks? If you‚Äôve raised a family locally ‚Äì yes, drop that into your conversation because families often discover hidden gems that others never looked for. Your deep local knowledge is a massive plus, so don‚Äôt hold back sharing it!

Pro Tip: Amp up your connection to the community. Talk up your knowledge of the local hotspots, weather patterns, and even those tricky traffic patterns. These insights directly affect your client‚Äôs happiness in a new location. Your local expertise is a significant part of your value proposition‚Äîdon‚Äôt be shy about sharing it.

Education, Experience & Professional Background

Be ready for questions about your educational journey, agent experience, and professional affiliations. Where‚Äôd you study? How long have you been an agent? Are you a full-time agent? What qualifications do you hold? While some might seem off-topic, they show your commitment to learning and professional growth. Everyone wants a ‚Äúsmart‚Äù agent.

Pro Tip: Chat about or show your education, ongoing training, and any certifications. The more you show dedication to staying informed and skilled, the more trust you’ll build with potential clients. Real estate‚Äôs always evolving, and clients love an agent who keeps up!

Saving Dough for Homebuyers

One of the most impactful realtor question you‚Äôll face is: How much money can you save me? Clients are becoming more aware that a savvy buyer agent can save them significant sums, sometimes even more than your fees.

Pro Tip: Come prepared with data. If you‚Äôve consistently saved your clients money, share those stats proudly. While you can‚Äôt guarantee future savings, having a track record speaks volumes about your negotiation skills and real estate market savvy. This is where you demonstrate that hiring you is an investment that pays for itself.

Steller Reviews

Even if they don‚Äôt ask outright, be the first to mention your reviews. What have past clients said about you?

Pro Tip: Point them to your Google Business Profile or Zillow where your reviews live. Proud of a solid five-star streak? Shout it out! Good reviews not only reflect your ability to deliver but also show you care about your reputation.

Winning in Multiple Offers

In a hot market, your clients will want to know your success rate in multiple-offer scenarios.

Pro Tip: Share your stats. High success rates here can really set you apart as a skilled competitor. While no agent can win every time, being able to show a strong track record of success will instill confidence in your potential clients.

Advising Against Risky Purchases

Homebuyers often get excited when they find great homes, sometimes overlooking potential pitfalls. They‚Äôll value a buyer agent who‚Äôs not afraid to flag risks. In fact, many surveys have stated that this is the biggest value people perceive that buyer agents bring to the table.¬† So, if they don‚Äôt ask, bring up your record.

Pro Tip: If possible, whip out a spreadsheet of stats to verify how many times you‚Äôve steered a buyer away from a potential bad or risky deal.¬† Concrete examples go a long way.

Brokerage Value

While your personal value as a real estate agent is paramount, the strength of your brokerage is another area of interest. Homebuyers want to know that they‚Äôre backed by the best.

Pro Tip: Be prepared to discuss what makes your brokerage stand out. If you‚Äôre with eXp Realty, for example, highlight the brokerage‚Äôs leadership in helping more families than any other brokerage in the United States and also your access to exclusive off-market properties.

Explain how being part of a leading brokerage benefits them from tools and resources to reputation and network leverage.

Fees and Discounts

Expect that homebuyers will be curious about your fees and if there‚Äôs room to negotiate. It‚Äôs a fair realtor question, as they‚Äôre trying to get the most bang for their buck. But start by explaining how discount fees generally mean less than full service.

Pro Tip: Be transparent and consistent about your fees and any discounts you offer. ¬†Even if you don‚Äôt do discounts, explain how you work to get them the best deal on their home. That saves them money too! Also, if your clients have benefited from some fee commission reduction like perhaps you buy all your clients a home warranty, highlight that.

Service Fee Menus

Along with discussing your fees with clients, consider offering fee menus.¬† For example, consider charging one fee for full service and a lower fee for limited service.¬† Doing that alone will help your potential clients understand the difference between the two and they‚Äôll love having a choice.

Pro Tip: Tailoring options to their needs shows you‚Äôre focused on providing value, not just making a sale.

The Real Deal on Commissions

And, again, on the topic of agent fees, do NOT miss the opportunity to explain what your actual take-home pay is for your earned fee.¬† It‚Äôs common for buyers to think agents pocket the full commission. This is your chance to set the record straight!

Pro Tip: Break down your real costs‚Äîhow much goes to the brokerage, team, expenses, etc. This transparency helps them more deeply appreciate your services and understand the value they‚Äôre getting. Don‚Äôt forget to recap that you don‚Äôt get paid at all unless you find them their dream home and secure it.

Wrapping it Up

Armed with this knowledge, you‚Äôre set to impress and win clients. Keep these points in mind, and you‚Äôll answer their realtor questions and also demonstrate your value convincingly.

For the full scoop on crafting winning buyer presentations, check out our blog or YouTube video about Real Estate Buyer Agent Consultations.

Also, a great way to be sure you cover all these realtor questions is to create a sharp Canva presentation. Or, when you partner will us at Smart Agent Alliance, you get our customizable buyer agent presentation ready for you to tweak and use to woe a new home buyer.

Join our FREE Team at eXp Realty

By partnering with us, you‚Äôll be joining the ONLY profitable public brokerage in the past 5 years that agents rank as the best brokerage to work for.

With Smart Agent Alliance you‚Äôll enjoy personalized day-to-day concierge care plus assets like customizable agent presentations, business automation, production checklists, customizable social media posts, and so much more.

As a member of our team, you‚Äôll also enjoy exclusive access to the Wolf Pack weekly webinars, Social Agent Academy for social media training, the Wolf Pack Hub for easy onboarding, Investor Army for investing and flipping houses training, and more.¬†

Don‚Äôt miss out on this amazing opportunity to maximize your earnings and build a thriving real estate business. Join eXp Realty today and experience unparalleled support from our FREE team.

Not quite convinced? No problem! Contact us to set up a meeting, request a link to a live webinar, and/or get all your questions answered via email, phone call, or video call. We‚Äôre here to help you succeed!

For more information, check out our eXp Realty overview, learn about our team benefits, and visit our Join Smart Agent Alliance page. Partner with us today and take your real estate career to the next level!

Frequently Asked Questions

What background should real estate agents share?

Share information about your roots. How long have you been around the area? How well do you know the local quirks? If you‚Äôve raised a family locally ‚Äì yes, drop that into your conversation because families often discover hidden gems that others never looked for. Your deep local knowledge is a massive plus, so don‚Äôt hold back sharing it!

What should realtors share about their education?

Share where you studied, what you studied, and all professional certifications. These show your commitment to learning and professional growth. Everyone wants a ‚Äúsmart‚Äù agent.

What should real estate agents say about fees and discounts?

Explain what fee you charge and why. If you charge a full-service fee, let home buyers know that discount fees generally come with less service. Be transparent and consistent with your real estate agent fees and any discounts you offer.

How can a real estate agent show home buyers savings?

Come to your buyer agent interview prepared with data. If you‚Äôve consistently saved your clients money, share those stats proudly. While you can‚Äôt guarantee future savings, having a track record speaks volumes about your negotiation skills and market savvy.

featuredImage.alt: 10 Realtor Questions to Expect from Home Buyers

metaDescription: Get ready to nail your next buyer agent interview! Learn the key Realtor questions, pro tips, and strategies to secure signed buyer agreements.
